awd_titl_txt: Building the capacity of Historically Black Colleges and Universities to increase competitiveness in DRL programs
awd_abstract_narration:
This broadening participation project will focus on a regional workshop aimed at increasing Historically Black Colleges and Universities' (HBCUs) capacity to develop high quality proposals for future competitions of various programs in the Division of Research on Learning. The proposed effort will occur through three specific steps involving a: (1) pre-workshop webinar to introduce and lay the foundation for the opportunity; (2) full two-day workshop to engage participants in a rigorous grant-writing exercise; and (3) post workshop follow-up to provide ongoing support and proposal development guidance. Through a theory-driven process, the goal is to establish some degree of conformity for maximizing grant productivity around strategies and ideas shown to be effective in retaining students in the STEM pipeline. 

The multi-tiered workshop will establish a launching pad for increasing attendees' capacity to build on prior knowledge and use best practices to improve future grant writing efforts. Specialized activities will help prepare HBCUs to increase their contributions to diversifying the future STEM workforce, support innovation and creativity in STEM fields, expand networking strategies, and promote opportunities to learn. Central to this capacity-building effort will be a focus on understanding the current research context and expectations for competitive participation in funding opportunities offered by NSF. This, in turn, will align with the Foundation's strategic direction for broadening participation in STEM through meaningful cutting-edge STEM education research. Resources from the workshop will be made available online to facilitate broader dissemination of information beneficial to HBCUs and other education institutions engaging in broadening participation efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Overview
Under this award, QEM planned and conducted two capacity building workshops to help science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) educators and researchers at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to develop competitive proposals for submission to the National Science Foundation (NSF)’s Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL) programs as well as provided targeted post-workshop support.
Proposal Development Workshop  
Workshop 1: The workshop was held on November 1-2, 2019, in Alexandria, VA. Participants comprised of individuals (5 CAREER proposal aspirants) and two-person faculty teams consisting of STEM faculty interested in submitting proposals to NSF DRL programs and other research-focused programs (AISL (5), CS4All (2), DR-K12 (6), ECR (5), ITEST (6), and STEM+C (2). Thirty-one (31) STEM and education/social science faculty from fifteen institutions attended the workshop.

Table 1. Institutions Represented at Workshop 1
 

Institution Institution
Alabama A&M University Hampton University
Alabama State University Howard University
Albany State University Langston University
Baton Rouge Community College Morgan State University
Bowie State University North Carolina A&T State University
Coppin State University Southern University and A&M College
Elizabeth City State University University of the District of Columbia
Fayetteville State University  

 

Workshop 2: QEM convened a virtual workshop on April 23, 2021, that supported 16 participants interested in submitting proposals to the NSF CAREER program. Participants were from 12 institutions representing 9 states and the District of Columbia.
Table 2. Institutions Represented at Workshop 2

Institution Institution
Bowie State University Prairie View A&M University
Central State University South Carolina State University
Fisk University   University of the District of Columbia  
Lincoln University-Missouri Virginia Union University
Meharry Medical College West Virginia State University
North Carolina A & T State University  Xavier University of Louisiana


Symposium Evaluation Summary: At the end of the workshops, participants received evaluation questionnaires to solicit feedback regarding their overall experience. One hundred (100) percent rated the workshops organization, clarity of goals, and usefulness of assistance offered at the workshops as “excellent or “very good”.
 When asked about the key highlights from the workshops, respondents remarked on the following:

1.    The opportunity to converse with the NSF officer was priceless. It was very beneficial.
2.    Knowing details about NSF workshop and knowing details about all opportunities and inner details of budget and other logistical needs  
3.    The hands-on activities and opportunities to meet program officers related our area
4.    Opportunity to network with past awardees and NSF program directors
5.    Getting to together to work with colleagues from own and other institutions, forming new collaborations, hearing from NSF program officers.

NSF Awards to Workshops Participants: A search of NSF’s awards database revealed  
that three individuals at the November 2019 and April 2021 workshops received awards amounting to over $2.3M. Though not direct from the DRL-supported programs, attending the DRL workshops could have increased their competitiveness in pursuing funding from other NSF programs.
 
Table 3. Awards to Past Workshop Participants                                                                                                       

Program Institution Award Amount 
Robert Noyce Scholarship Program Albany State University   $1,486,640.00
Symbiosis Infection & Immunity North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University $628,512.00
Office of Multidisciplinary Ac South Carolina State University $229,706.00
    Total $2,344858.00 


About QEM: The QEM Network was established in 1990 as a non-profit organization in Washington, DC, dedicated to improving education for minorities throughout the nation. QEM works with minority and non-minority individuals, organizations, and institutions to help coordinate and energize efforts to improve the education of minorities, particularly in STEM. QEM’s technical assistance projects support institutional efforts to ensure that students who graduate with degrees in STEM disciplines are well-prepared to successfully pursue STEM graduate study or transition into the STEM workforce.
 


Last Modified: 12/21/2021
Modified by: Erin Lynch
